items.title: Option trading for range-bound market: Shubham Agarwal
items.description: Range bound markets are also equally profitable, if traded effectively using Options, explains Shubham Agarwal.

items.title: Stocks slump on latest tariffs, soft jobs data
items.description: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 542.40 points, or 1.23%, to 43,588.58, the S&P 500 lost 101.38 points, or 1.60%, to 6,238.01 and the Nasdaq Composite lost 472.32 points, or 2.24%, to 20,650.13.

items.title: Market reports longest weekly losing streak in two years; rupee weakens
items.description: The Indian rupee shed 100 paise to close at 87.52 per dollar on August 1 against the July 25 closing of 86.52.

items.title: Chartist Talk: This VP shares 2 buy and 2 sell picks amid market caution; Nifty at risk below 24,400
items.description: The 24,400–24,350 zone is expected to act as an immediate support for Nifty. A sustained break below this could further accelerate the downside. On the flip side, the 50-day EMA zone of 24,900–24,950 now stands as a crucial hurdle, and any meaningful recovery would need to clear this zone with conviction, said Sudeep Shah of SBI Securities.

items.title: Bulk deals: SR Foundation buys half a percent stake in Belrise Industries
items.description: Belrise Industries shares has seen buying interest for fourth consecutive week, rising nearly 37 percent during the period.

items.title: Top gainers & losers: Stocks that moved the most on August 1
Business in the Week Ahead (August 4-8, 2025)
items.description: Be it trade or monetary policy, the US reset is making many go back to the drawing board. What should be your market toolkit for the coming week? What are the markers you just can’t avoid? There are lots, apart from a couple of key credit policy calls, and the earnings dashboard. Hop on

items.title: Taking Stock: Nifty below 24,600 in fifth week of fall, big selloff in pharma
items.description: Tracking weak global cues, the indices had opened lower but recovered, however, a mid-session profit booking and extended selloff in the final hour dragged Nifty below 24,550, ending near day's low.

items.title: Symphony Approves FY25 Financials, Declares ₹8/Share Final Dividend
items.description: Symphony Approves FY25 Financials, Declares ₹8/Share Final Dividend

items.title: Markets slide for second session amid global weakness, tariff Concerns
items.description: Asian markets were largely in the red, with indices in South Korea, Japan, China and Hong Kong trading lower. The negative trend followed weak closing on Wall Street, and US futures indicating a subdued start, further dampening investor confidence.

items.title: Textile stocks extend losses after Trump tariffs; Gokaldas Exports, Pearl Global, KPR Mill down up to 6%
items.description: Textile stocks: Bangladesh has secured a 20 percent tariff deal with US. Indian textile exports will now face higher tariffs on exports than their rivals from Bangladesh.

items.title: Live: Nifty ends fifth week lower, slips below 24,600-mark | Closing Bell
items.description: Nifty Extends Losing Streak To Fifth Week. Nifty Slips Below 24,700; Sensex Down 400 Pts. Barring FMCG, All Sectors Down In The Red. FMCG Best Sectoral Performer This Week. Realty, Bank Worst Performer This Week. Pharma Sees Severe Cuts On Trump's Letters. Broader Mkts Underperform; India Vix Up 2%. Nifty 50 Gainers: Trent, Asian Paints, Nestle. Nifty 50 Laggards: Sun Pharma, Dr Reddy's, Cipla. Join Lovisha Darad and Yatin Mota as they break down the week’s market action and highlight stocks to watch.

items.title: ABB India share price falls 2.01%
items.description: With the stock price at Rs 5,399.50, ABB India's performance reflects the current market dynamics and investor reactions within the NIFTY NEXT 50 landscape.

items.title: Bharti Airtel share price falls 1.39%
items.description: With the stock's last traded price at Rs 1,887.70, Bharti Airtel has seen a decrease of 1.39% in today's session.

items.title: Retail Losses, Jane Street & Weekly Options: What Needs Fixing in F&O?
items.description:
With retail investors suffering massive losses and fresh allegations of market manipulation involving Jane Street, the need to reform India’s derivatives market has never been more urgent. The challenge lies in striking the right balance—ensuring the market stays vibrant and efficient, without turning into a playground for speculation and manipulation.
Moneycontrol’s panel discussion on reforming the F&O segment brought together four seasoned experts to explore actionable solutions—from curbing excessive retail participation to rethinking weekly options.
